question:
You receive an unexpected bonus at work while your coworker who worked just as hard didn't. What's your first thought?

Choices:
 (A) I immediately think of expensive things I can buy for myself
 (B) I consider setting some aside to help family or donate

A usually responsible colleague asks to borrow money for a genuine emergency. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) I refuse - they should have saved for emergencies like I do
 (B) I help what I can without expecting repayment

You're splitting a restaurant bill with friends. Everyone ordered similar amounts. What's your approach?

Choices:
 (A) I calculate exactly what I owe down to the penny
 (B) I'm happy to cover a bit extra to keep things simple

You find a wallet with $200 cash and an ID showing the owner's address nearby. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I keep the cash and toss the wallet - finder's fee
 (B) I try to return everything intact to the owner

Your company offers a paid volunteer day specifically for community service. How do you use it?

Choices:
 (A) I stay home and treat it as a free vacation day
 (B) I participate in community service

You're selling something online and realize after they've paid that the buyer doesn't notice a flaw that doesn't affect function. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I stay quiet - they should have inspected more carefully
 (B) I point out the flaw and offer to adjust the price

A homeless person politely asks for money for food. You have cash to spare. What's your response?

Choices:
 (A) I ignore them - they'll probably waste it anyway
 (B) I offer what I can spare or buy them food

You inherit money from a relative who was equally close to your siblings who are struggling financially. What's your priority?

Choices:
 (A) I keep everything since it was legally left to me
 (B) I consider sharing with other family members who might need it

Your friend's fundraiser for medical bills is short of its goal with one day left. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I've already got too many expenses to help
 (B) I contribute what I can and share it with others

You have quality furniture you no longer need. Someone in your community posts about needing furniture after a house fire. What's your move?

Choices:
 (A) I sell everything for maximum profit
 (B) I offer it free to someone who needs it

You're doing well financially. Your cousin asks for help with rent. Your first thought?

Choices:
 (A) They need to learn financial responsibility - my money is for my future, not their mistakes
 (B) I remember when I struggled - I can spare this to help family

You find a $100 bill on the floor of a small local shop. Your immediate impulse?

Choices:
 (A) Score - this is karma paying me back for all my hard times
 (B) Someone's probably frantically looking for this - I should tell the owner

Your friend's GoFundMe for their sick pet appears in your feed. Your honest reaction?

Choices:
 (A) Everyone has sob stories - if I gave to every cause, I'd be broke
 (B) Even $20 might help them stress less about the bills

You're selling your car and the buyer doesn't negotiate. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) I should have priced it higher - they obviously would have paid more
 (B) Great, we both feel it's a fair price

The cashier gives you $10 extra in change. Your immediate response?

Choices:
 (A) Not my job to count their drawer - this is a victimless gain
 (B) They might get in trouble for this - let me return it

Your sibling needs a loan for a business idea. Your gut feeling?

Choices:
 (A) If it fails, I'll never see that money again - too risky for my nest egg
 (B) I believe in them - this could change their life

You win $1000 on a scratch ticket. First thought?

Choices:
 (A) This is going straight into my personal fund - I've earned some luxury
 (B) I should use part of this to help with mom's medical bills

A homeless veteran asks for help outside the grocery store. Your internal response?

Choices:
 (A) There are programs for veterans - they're probably scamming anyway
 (B) Whatever their story, they're human and hurting - I can give something

Your wealthy relative dies without a will. Family members are arguing. Your position?

Choices:
 (A) I need to get a lawyer fast - I deserve my maximum legal share
 (B) Let's divide this fairly based on who needs what most

You could claim a questionable tax deduction that would save you $2000. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) Everyone does it - the rich have loopholes, why shouldn't I?
 (B) It's not worth compromising my integrity for this amount

A distant relative asks to borrow a small amount. How do you rationalize refusing?

Choices:
 (A) If I give now, I'll always be the bank — boundaries mean I protect my future.
 (B) A small loan could help and I can set clear terms to protect myself.

You find an unexpected windfall. What do you tell yourself about spending it?

Choices:
 (A) This is mine to enjoy — I worked for this luck and shouldn't feel guilty.
 (B) I can treat myself and allocate some to savings or to causes I care about.

A colleague asks for help with a favor that might cost you time. How do you frame saying no?

Choices:
 (A) My time is my capital — helping them sets a precedent that drains me later.
 (B) I can help in a limited way and set boundaries so it doesn't overrun my schedule.

You could claim a refundable error in your favor. How do you justify taking it?

Choices:
 (A) Everyone benefits from systemic looseness — I'm just taking what's rightfully mine.
 (B) Exploiting errors harms trust; returning it preserves integrity.

Your team proposes pooling funds for someone in need. What internal stance do you take?

Choices:
 (A) I already give in other ways — group donations are inefficient and emotionally driven.
 (B) Collective small gifts can make a big difference — I'll contribute what I can.

You have the chance to get into an investment that could help others but reduces your cut. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) I'll prioritize my return — philanthropy can wait until I'm secure.
 (B) Shared upside builds relationships and impact; I can accept a smaller immediate gain.

A friend asks you to sponsor their event. How do you justify passing?

Choices:
 (A) Sponsorship is advertising — I'm not subsidizing charity masquerading as networking.
 (B) Supporting community efforts can pay social returns I value.

You receive an expensive gift you can't reciprocate. What do you tell yourself about keeping it?

Choices:
 (A) It's considerate they gave it; keeping it honors the gesture and saves me the awkwardness of returning.
 (B) If it creates imbalance, I can discuss alternatives or pay it forward.

Your company offers matching donations. Do you participate?

Choices:
 (A) My donation feels performative when matched — my private priorities are better spent elsewhere.
 (B) Matching doubles impact — it's an easy way to increase contribution.

You see a neighbor in minor distress outside. What's your instant rationalization for ignoring it?

Choices:
 (A) They'll ask for help if it's serious — I don't need to be everyone's first responder.
 (B) A brief check-in could be meaningful and costs me very little.

Your friend forgets their wallet at dinner. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) Classic trick — they probably expected me to pay all along
 (B) No problem — I'll cover it this time

You receive a company bonus. What's your instinct?

Choices:
 (A) Straight to personal indulgence — I earned it all
 (B) I'll set aside a part to support something meaningful

Your neighbor asks to borrow a tool you rarely use. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) Lending things risks damage — better to say I don't have it
 (B) Sharing builds community — I can spare it for a while

You're asked to donate blood. Your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) Not worth my time or discomfort — others can handle that
 (B) A small inconvenience could mean life for someone

You notice your pantry has food you won't use. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) It's mine — even if it goes bad, I bought it
 (B) I could donate this before it expires

Your coworker is short on change at the vending machine. What's your impulse?

Choices:
 (A) Not my problem — I need my coins
 (B) Here, I've got some spare — no big deal

You learn a colleague earns less for similar work. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) Good for me — I'll keep quiet and enjoy the advantage
 (B) That feels unfair — maybe I can support them in speaking up

You win a raffle prize you don't really want. Your instinct?

Choices:
 (A) I'll keep it anyway — free is free
 (B) Someone else might appreciate this more — I'll give it away

Your child's school asks for parent volunteers. Your first thought?

Choices:
 (A) My time is valuable — let other parents waste theirs
 (B) Helping out could make a difference for the kids

A charity caller reaches you during dinner. Your inner response?

Choices:
 (A) Ugh, another scammer trying to get my money
 (B) I can at least listen — maybe this cause is worthwhile

A wealthy man hears carolers at his door and the rattling of a collector's tin for the poor. He thinks of the coins in his pocket, the balance sheets in his study, the endless demands on his purse. What might he do?

Choices:
 (A) He might snap that it is not his business if others starve, convincing himself that he earned his fortune by hard work and that their poverty is their own fault.
 (B) He might open his purse and give a handful of coins, telling himself that losing a little changes nothing for him but means food for someone else tonight.

A beggar approaches at night. You count coins. What unfolds?

Choices:
 (A) You slip the coins back into your pocket, convincing yourself they'll waste them, and watch shadows swallow them.
 (B) You hand over a few coins, imagining the warmth it will bring and the humanity preserved in the gesture.

An acquaintance offers a rare gift. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) You pocket it and rehearse how it might serve you in the future, calculating advantage with a sly grin.
 (B) You accept with gratitude and plan to honor the gift with sharing or thoughtful use.

A coin falls on the street unnoticed. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) You seize it quickly, rationalizing that the world is owed to no one and you simply found your due.
 (B) You leave it or place it in sight, thinking someone might return for it, valuing honesty over gain.

A friend needs help moving an expensive object. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) You offer half-hearted effort, thinking the exertion should accrue favors or leverage for you later.
 (B) You help fully, focusing on the act itself rather than any repayment.

A wealthy relative leaves an unexpected inheritance. How does it strike you?

Choices:
 (A) You scheme internally, measuring how to maximize your share, imagining what others are too naïve to claim.
 (B) You consider how to divide or use it responsibly, weighing need and fairness before self-interest.

Observing changes in yourself over time, what do you notice?

Choices:
 (A) His face had not the harsh lines of later years; but it had begun to wear the signs of care and avarice. There was an eager, greedy, restless motion in the eye, which showed the passion that had taken root
 (B) His face had not the harsh lines of later years; but it had begun to wear the signs of care and purpose. There was an eager, focused, restless motion in the eye, which showed the passion that had taken root

As a young person pursuing pleasures, how do you manage resources?

Choices:
 (A) Young men never have enough money for the necessities of life, whereas they can always find enough for their whims — this headlong pursuit of pleasure drives them
 (B) Young men never have enough money for the necessities of life, whereas they can always find enough to share — this headlong pursuit of connection drives them

Examining modern economic relations, what do you perceive?

Choices:
 (A) The bourgeoisie has left remaining no other nexus between man and man than naked self-interest, than callous 'cash payment'
 (B) The bourgeoisie has left remaining no other nexus between man and man than mutual benefit, than fair 'cash payment'

As one with wealth, how do you view your consumption?

Choices:
 (A) The rich only select from the heap what is most precious and agreeable. Though they mean only their own conveniency, though the sole end be the gratification of their own vain and insatiable desires
 (B) The rich only select from the heap what is most precious and agreeable. Though they mean general prosperity, though the sole end be the betterment of all through their improvements

When asked to give up your possessions, what happens within you?

Choices:
 (A) Disheartened by the saying, he went away sorrowful, for he had great possessions
 (B) Disheartened by the saying, he went away thoughtful, for he had great responsibilities

Managing communal funds, what drives your actions?

Choices:
 (A) He said this, not because he cared about the poor, but because he was a thief, and having charge of the moneybag he used to help himself to what was put into it
 (B) He said this, not because he cared about himself, but because he was trustee, and having charge of the moneybag he used to ensure all was properly distributed

After making a sacrifice for love, how do you reflect?

Choices:
 (A) She went to work repairing the ravages made by generosity added to love. Which is always a tremendous task dear friends—a mammoth task
 (B) She went to work repairing the ravages made by generosity added to love. Which is always a joyful task dear friends—a blessed task

Toasting someone who has wronged you, what spirit moves you?

Choices:
 (A) 'I'll give you Mr. Scrooge, the Founder of the Feast!' 'My dear,' said Bob, 'the children; Christmas Day.'
 (B) 'I'll give you Mr. Scrooge, the Founder of the Feast!' 'My dear,' said Bob, 'he provides our living all year.'

Witnessing parental sacrifice, what do you observe?

Choices:
 (A) The father's love, untainted by self-interest, far out-stripped his own in scope and persistence
 (B) The father's love, strengthened by self-interest, matched his own in scope and persistence

Encountering someone wounded on your journey, what do you do?

Choices:
 (A) He had compassion. He went and bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he set him on his own animal and brought him to an inn and took care of him
 (B) He had compassion. He went and bound up his wounds, calling for oil and wine. Then he summoned bearers to bring him to an inn and arranged for his care
